channel.title: BufferedImages
channel.description:
Okay. I have an array of BufferedImage objects that are to be used as tiles in a game. They are 24 by 24 pixels, and in a 16 by 16 grid.
I am going to be using it to draw a background of a map, and since I don't want to have to loop through every one of them to draw it, is there a way to combine them all into one BufferedImage object?
BufferedImage[] backgroundLayer is the array that the tiles are stored in, and there are 256 of them. I want them all to be combined into a single BufferedImage.

Class methods and fields are the things marked with static, meaning they can be invoked or referenced from other classes with out having to create a new instance for that class.
That means the JVM loads all those other fields and methods at runtime.

Um. No? The static modifier has nothing to do with access rights, that belongs to: public, protected, package, and private modifiers… Static simply means there’s 1 copy per instance of the application, and do not have to be instantiated. IE: Math.anything
[/quote]
I see you are illiterate.
I said they are loaded once per run of the JVM with a classfile, which causes much overhead waste.
Like class System in java.lang, all of it’s members are loaded at JVM runtime, like the PrintStreams err and out and many of it’s methods.[/quote]
But that’s wrong, they’re once per instance, I can have 50 instances of an applet in ONE JVM and each one has its own copy of the static methods…

“Illiterate.” I suppose is better than “completely unintelligent.”

item.dc:creator: @VB7_Rocks VB7 Rocks
item.description:
@VB7_Rocks wrote:

[quote=“remove_later, post:16, topic:149713”][quote author=sh!ft link=topic=205114.msg1809042#msg1809042 date=1191800177]

Yes, you can pass a BufferedImage as the argument for it’s a subclass of Image.

Are you sure? I get this when compiling:

[pre]gfxHandler.java:64: cannot find symbol
symbol : method drawImage(java.awt.image.BufferedImage,int,int)
location: class java.awt.Graphics
currentBackground.getGraphics().drawImage(tilese
t[0], x * 24, y * 24);
^
1 error[/pre]

From what I understand, it thinks that there is no method called drawImage that takes an Image and two int arguments?

This is because the code is incorrect.

Try:

currentBackground.getGraphics().drawImage(tilese t[0], x * 24, y * 24, null);

The issue lies in the fact that the drawImage method contains a 4th variable, “ImageObserver”.
[/quote]

Oh silly me, forgot to metion he forgot to pass an ImageObserver object as an argument.

Oh, and VB7, try following proper Java programming concepts, like naming your class with a capital.
So instead of class gfxHandler, we have GfxHandler, or better, GraphicsHandler.
Lastly, don’t make so many things class functions (methods) and variables (fields), overhead waste
Better to use instance functions (methods) and variables (fields).[/quote]

Hmm. I’ve always named things starting with lower case, hehe.

And about the class functions, why would it be overhead waste if I’m just using an abstract class for a single GUI? Example being the gfx class, it’s abstract and contains the tile information that a GUI class uses to display. If I’m not planning on having duplicate GUI’s, why bother with instances of the gfx class?

item.description:
@VB7_Rocks wrote:

remove_later:

[quote]myBufferedImage.getGrahpics().drawImage(tileset[i], x, y);

VB7 Rocks, seeing you put an ‘i’ for the index of the array, it seems you’re using a for-loop.
Instead use a for-each loop, like so, assuming the array tileset is an array of Image objects:

for(Image i : tileset) myBufferedImage.getGraphics().drawImage(i, x, y);
I see you already know what to replace the ‘x’ and ‘y’ with, so I’ll leave you at that.[/quote]

So the .getGraphics().drawImage(image, x, y) will draw an image to an existing BufferedImage, right?

Also, does it matter in drawImage(image, x, y) if it’s a BufferedImage you pass as an argument, or does it have to be an Image object?
